As a Chinese-American who has no illusions about China, I often am amused at how ignorant other Americans are re. the country. Most Americans rightly decry our country's malaise yet look to China with wide-eyed fascination, without any clue as to what the country is like.

China is not some benign country with no intention to bully its neighbors or curtail our interests in the region. In the past few years it has used its economic and military clout to confront its neighbors, from South Korea, Japan, the Philippines, to Vietnam, in a series of provocative territorial skirmishes, many of which have cost the lives of the citizens of our allies in the region.

This move is exceptionally modest; 2,500 Marines is not a large force and is not likely to cost much. It is not a grand realignment of US forces, nor does it entail expansion of the "military industrial complex," whatever that nebulous concept may be.

Over 5 trillion in trade is conducted through the region's sea routes, with over 1 trillion owing to US trade. The area is of vital commercial interest to our economy, and sending a signal that we intend to protect our economic interests is needed.

In the past few years nearly all of our allies, from Singapore, Australia, to Japan have requested an increased military presence in the region. Even countries not aligned to us have driven home the point that they want a stronger US presence. This presence is not some new development, anyone familiar with Australia or the Philippines knows that the US once stationed troops in the region and once had a stronger presence, in just the last decade.

The US needs to reassert its Asian presence, both through the use of increased diplomacy, as SOS Clinton has admirably done, and to reorganize its military presence to leave a symbolic mark. The debate is whether or not this move is the right decision, not that it signals an intent to vastly expand military power.

What works for some people doesn't work for others. While stretching (before or after the main exercise) may not matter on average, you have to find out for yourself whether it helps or not. For me, perhaps very old habits die hard, but it has always been the case that if I jump on the bike or on a treadmill or start running before I have stretched my calves, I will likely cramp up. And so I do some leg stretches of hamstrings, quads, and calves to prevent cramping. Should everybody do it? Probably not. But if I don't do it, I regret it. Similarly, before I do weight work with my lats, or chest work for that matter, it helps me to stretch by hanging on a bar. Should others doit? Maybe not. But they might find it helpful.

I don't think it's possible to set hard-and-fast rules that suit everybody. But you have to pay attention to what happens to your body during and after exercise, and see whether stretching (before, during, or after) helps you or not.

Dr W sent in the following set of remarkable images with this note:

"I'm in the middle of a professional rejuvenation -- discovered a Chipmunk Basic interpreter that seems to work well on the Mac and I'm reviving some long-dormant Fortran-based projects from the past. So, in the middle of that I thought I'd try it on generating graphics for multiply sliced pies. The attached graphic corresponds to slices made by 21 points on the rim of a pizza (outlined in red). This is the program that created it, listed herewith:

2 graphics window 5,30,705,530
4 dim x(100),y(100)

6 nang = 21
8 pi = 4*atan(1)
10 dang = 2*pi/nang
12 xctr = 300
14 yctr = 250
16 r = 200

18 graphics color 100,0,0
20 graphics circle xctr-r,yctr-r,xctr+r,yctr+r
22 graphics color 0,0,0

24 ang = 0
26 for i = 0 to nang
28 x(i) = xctr+r*cos(ang)
30 y(i) = yctr+r*sin(ang)
32 ang = ang+dang
34 next i

36 for j = 0 to nang
38 x0 = x(j)
40 y0 = y(j)
42 for i = 0 to nang
44 moveto x0,y0
46 lineto x(i),y(i)
48 next i
50 next j
52 stop

The concentric envelope patterns are of interest, obviously.

Regarding the comment about how people feel free to ask pregnant women intrusive questions, I couldn't agree more. In fact, it seems to me that as soon as a woman gets pregnant, somehow her body becomes public property, with complete strangers patting her stomach as she tries to retrieve boxed grape juice in the grocery store. Not to mention engaging in discussions regarding the act upon which the pregnancy is predicated. So I guess it shouldn't be too surprising that everybody wants to tell her how and when to give birth - which doesn't mean it's OK, of course.

When you create a law based largely on emotion, it should come as no surprise to find that all of it's implications have not been carefully considered.  Charging people with felonies for failing to comply with an ambiguously-worded law simply defies logic.
I keep wondering what it is going to take to get the government to listen to us, the People.  We want ILLEGAl Immigrant OUT!

I propose that all illegals shall be denied public services--those who illegally drive over the speed limit, illegally jay-walk, and illegally don't pay taxes on items bought over the internet. Then we shall send all those illegals back to where they or their ancestors came from. They certainly don't deserve to live in the land of the law-abiding free.
that bill rocks. Wish it were here!
Interestingly, under this law the farmers are unable to reap what they sow, but the politicians are about to.

Alabama's immigration law is much too liberal and should be modified in such a manner as that no illegal alien would dare to come within a thousand miles of the last good place in America, which is to say Alabama.

Only two dynamics that stand to rapidly worsen the future of these United States -- (1) continued growth of the nation's human population, and (2) continued lack of public acknowledgment by the federal government, coincident with a quickly implemented for conservation, of the coming oil crises. The future in plain sight.

The President's speech to the Australian Parliament was a superb mix of shared heritage, shared destiny and a commitment to common values. The 2,500 marines is a strong symbolic message that the US sees the Asia Pacific region as both a strategic and economic focal point for the development of both US and regional interests. They can always seek to add more troops and extend their presence in Australia. Both sides of Aust. politics support this since they can see the sense and mutual benefit.

I guess there is some truth to the stereotype of white Alabamians;

As the law is written, the stakes of wrong interpretation are high. Agencies or officials that do not carry out the law to its fullest extent could be liable for civil or criminal penalties. Observing a violation of the law and failing to report it is a crime. A clerk who violates Section 30 could be facing a felony charge.

So are they all going to arrest each other, or do we have to send in the FBI and National Guard to impose law & order as the state troopers will all be in jail for arresting, or not arresting each other.

Research this state, you will be amazed, especially the tax structure, it is a leader in taking far more federal tax dollars than it contributes. T-party solutions in action. This is the state that elected Gingrich to congress. You should know that LA refers to lower Alabama.

WHY is it that those interested in these draconian, simplistic laws which always seem so easy always fail to see unintended consequences. i guess when you appeal to the lowest common denominator, that's always a problem.

The more USA spends its tax dollars on the military and imperial ventures, the better it will be for the developing economies to catch up with the American standard of living: by investing their resources in education, infrastructure, research, healthcare, and other priorities that will improve the welfare of their people.

South Korea – 28,500
Japan – 40,178
Philippines - 182
Diego Garcia - 286
Jakarta, Indonesia - 30
Singapore – 157
Thailand – 162
Malaysia - 16

Add now 100 to 2,500 U.S. Marines in Australia.

This is an approximation of current (known) U.S. military installations in Asia.

Don't we already have enough resources committed to Asia? This doesn't include military alliances with Japan, South Korea, Indonesia and Taiwan. Now Australia.

Sorry Mr. President! This citizen believes we cannot afford it. Australia is perfectly capable of defending itself - just like the other Asian nations where we have bases.

Yes we defended Australia during the Second World War due to the very real threat of invasion of Japanese forces from occupied Papua New Guinea. That was a different war in a different age.

The threat China poses is not so much military, it is economic. And it's not even really a threat considering that American corporations have been drooling over Chinese cheap labor and their billion-person market since Nixon's visit in the 70's.

Like some of the previous comments here have stated, China could defeat us (and is) not by war, but by underwriting our currency. The U.S. owes China 2 trillion dollars. Why do they even need to fire a shot. The Peoples Republic already has us by our collective wallet.

2,500 Marines in Australia is more a political message than anything else. What the Australians really should be worried about is possible terrorist cells in Indonesia (remember the Bali bombing in 2005).

The Administration is doing what it wants to do anyway, but still, I think many Americans think this is just another needless example military over-reach.

This article lumps in two causes for increased health care costs--smoking and obesity--and then discusses them as if they are the same.

Smoking, while additive, is ultimately under the smoker's control.

Obesity is a much more complex, multifactorial problem. The evidence is becoming increasingly clear that weight is less under the control of the individual than many people would like to think. Epigenetics, maternal effects, early environment childhood environment, etc, greatly influence a person's weight. The evidence also makes it clear that once an individual is obese, it is very difficult for them to lose that weight permanently. The vast majority do not succeed in losing the weight and of those that do, most regain it within a few years. Complicating the issue further is the fact that the scientific evidence also indicates that very mild weight loss for the obese (~7-8% body mass) can have very positive effects on other aspects of their health, and that it might not even be necessary for them to lose it all. Finally, some obese people have genuine metabolic disorders or gain the weight as a side effect of medications for other illnesses. My concern is that a company policy that penalizes the obese with increased penalties will not take into account the complexity of the issue.

I'm fine with higher penalties for smokers, but not the obese. A better strategy to paying for the increased health costs of obesity would be taxes on soda and juice.

There is a billboard near Chicago that says, "Obesity isn't a choice, it's a disease." It is a true saying as far as it goes. What it needs to then go on and say is, "so choose what you CAN do about it and get your substantial self over to a 12 steps group." We can say the same for smokers. One very welcome help in that direction would be to make those practices that contribute to the morbidity of those diseases more expensive. YES!

I am a non-smoker, but I object to this. The point of insurance is to spread out risk equally. Cigarettes are legal, smoking is legal, tobacco companies deliberately make their products addictive. No penalties.
Overweight people should definitely pay more for health insurance.  They have chosen an unhealthy lifestyle.

This should be presented as a discount for people who don't smoke and who aren't obese rather than a penalty for those who DO smoke and who ARE obese.

Sure some people are obese because of a thyroid problem or because of certain medications, but that's a small minority of those who are obese.

Besides, they aren't saying you can't be overweight, just not obese and there is a distinction. It just isn't reasonable to expect everyone else to shoulder the financial burden for other people's poor decisions.

Sincerely,
5'2" RN tired of lifting/repositioning/pushing obese patients.

I notice that alcohol is not included in this Big Brother approach to regulating life styles.  And when you consider all the toxic effects of drinking beyond moderation (for themselves, their community, and the unwary public at large), I think it only appropriate to ask employees to disclose their drinking habits and penalize them accordingly if they go over a 'prescribed limit.'  A citation for drunk driving? for domestic abuse? And when it comes to health insurance, think of all the dangers that beset us everyday.  Let's tabulate them as well and add them to the list.

Poster 47 EhWaston writes:

"I can virtually guarantee that, over time, the health cost 'penalties' will become another creepy, sneaky way for employers to simply shift health care costs to employees."

Oh the horror of it!! You mean people might have to pay for their own health care rather than try to freeload off others?

I'm okay with this, but under a few conditions:

All companies who want to implement these surcharges must provide clean, modern gyms onsite for their employees and pay them for the time they spend exercising.

All food companies who provide food to grocery stores must agree to not use genetically modified crops, grains, or Frankenfood.

Ban fast food, pharmaceutical, cigarette and alcohol advertising from all media.

Cities and towns must be logically planned (or re-designed) to allow all citizens to bike, run, and exercise safely outdoors and businesses must be located in a distance no greater than 20 minutes by car for 90% of its workers.

Any company that engages in a business that is harmful to human health (oil companies, tobacco companies, etc) must pay 90% of their profit to a general fund which will send tax rebates to every US citizen who complies with these new health insurance rules.

All medical billing sent to any consumer must be pre-approved by a non-affiliated citizen committee that will ensure that Americans are not being price-gouged. Additionally, all drug companies must make their prescription medications available to US customers for the same cost, or less, than they charge their non-US customers.

Fair is fair, right? Let's Make a deal!
